Some 200 mayors met this week in Washington for the U.S.
Conference of Mayors.
Key issues covered were: homeland security, poverty, hurricane relief and the economy.
One other important topic was how cities should be preparing for a possible avian flu pandemic.
Here to talk with us about this are Mayor Greg Nickels of Seattle and Mayor David Wallace of Sugar Land, Texas.
Thank you both for being here.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Now, Congress has recently approved funding for avian flu preparation.
Right.
Where would you put federal money in your preparation plan?
Where do you think the biggest need is?
Well, I think that there are a number of different areas.

We need to make sure that we have chain of command for our police, fire, public works; some of those essential types of services that you have to have if you have a third of your workforce that is off.
One area that I would add to what Mayor Wallace has said is what's called surge capacity in the healthcare system.
In our region, we would expect a 1.2 million people to be infected.
Probably half of them would be clinical ill.
And so that means tens of thousands of emergency room visits, of doctors' visits.
And our healthcare system really is not at capacity to be able to deal with that.

So the federal government, I think, has a role to provide us with some planning dollars and maybe some capacity building; so that we can add on to the number of people we can give help to at a point at which they can still be helped.
I think we learned a lot of lessons as a result of Katrina, as a result of Rita.

And one of the things that we did after Katrina within 48 hours we had converted our old city hall, we had recently moved into a new one, our old city hall into a hurricane resource center where we had a Level One trauma.
We had X-ray.
We had people looking for jobs, looking for housing, food, a number of different things.
But what we solved was the creation of that type of facility to react.
And now, that's something that we are using as a best practice as if we had to do something.
If we had to convert our schools into these clinics, what physical structures do we have and how do we best move forward with that?
Mayor Nickels, you've actually received an award at this mayors' conference, a Best Practices Award for your plan.
What are the key elements of the plan?
Well, the key elements are first to understand that it's inevitable, not this particular flu but a pandemic is inevitable.
It happens on a cycle and we're overdue.
Secondly, while generally the pandemics are not orders of magnitude worse than the general flu that we can expect to see every year.
In 1918-1919, the worse case, millions of people died, three million in the United States.
And we need to understand and prepare for the worst, hope for the best.
How do you communicate that to your citizens without panicking them?
Well, you start I think simply.
If you go to Seattle now, you'll see in many public restrooms a card that tells you about hand washing.
We begin by telling people make sure you cover when you cough and you sneeze.
If we get into a situation where we think a pandemic is beginning, we obviously ratchet that up and just talk to people, you know, real simply about things you can do to protect yourself.
